metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Shoorji Vallabhdas and Co.

facts.text: The assessee firm consisted of three partners, Shoorji Vallabhdas and his two sons, Pratapsinh and Vikramsinh.
The assessee firm was the managing agents of several shipping companies including the Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd., and the New Dholera Steamships Ltd.

Agreement with Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd. on September 16, 1938, modified on December 7, 1943; with New Dholera Steamships Ltd. on June 8, 1946. Entitled to 10 per cent. of the freight charged as commission.

Between April 1, 1947, and December 31, 1947, commission at 10 per cent. of freight: Rs. 1,71,885 from Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd. and Rs. 2,56,815 from New Dholera Steamships Ltd. Credited in books of assessee firm to itself with corresponding debit to shipping companies.
In 1947, the assessee firm floated two private limited companies: Shoorji Vallabhdas Ltd. and Pratapsingh Ltd.
On November 20, 1947, assessee firm expressed desire to resign from managing agency and have the two private limited companies appointed on same terms.
Two shareholders of Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd. objected on November 27, 1947, suggesting commission be 10 per cent. of profits or 2 1/2 per cent. of freight.
Board of Malabar Steamship Co. Ltd. invited assessee firm to offer reduction to 2 1/2 per cent. of freight for current and future years.
Assessee firm offered: whilst insisting on full right, voluntarily agree to reduction to 2 1/2 per cent. of total freight for current and future years as mutually agreed.
Similar procedure followed for New Dholera Steamships Ltd.
On December 30, 1947, extraordinary general meetings held; two private limited companies appointed managing agents from January 1, 1948. Offer accepted.
At annual general meetings in December 1948, commission reduced from 10 per cent. to 2 1/2 per cent. of freight.
Assessee firm gave up 75 per cent. of earnings: Rs. 1,36,903 (Malabar) and Rs. 2,00,625 (New Dholera).
Assessment year 1948-49, previous year ending March 31, 1948.
Income-tax Officer and Appellate Assistant Commissioner: larger commission accrued during previous year, assessable; amount given up not expenditure u/s 10(2)(xv).
Appellate Tribunal: Accountant Member for rejection; Judicial Member and President for assessee - agreement to reduce during account year, larger income neither accrued nor received.
Two questions referred to High Court at instance of Commissioner.
Bombay High Court judgment dated October 1, 1958: first question negative, declined second. Certified fit for appeal u/s 66A(2).

legal_issues.text: Whether the two sums of Rs. 1,36,903 and Rs. 2,00,625 are income of the previous year ended March 31, 1948?
If yes to i1, whether they represent an item of expenditure permissible under section 10(2)(xv) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922?

petitioner_arguments.text: Income had already accrued to the assessee firm in the year of account, and was thus assessable.
Arrangement amounted to a voluntary gift by the assessee firm to the shipping companies.
Books kept on mercantile basis showed commission as each amount of freight entered.
Managed companies dealt with accounts only in December 1948, after previous year; subsequent events do not alter position.

respondent_arguments.text: Events during account year sufficient to show income neither accrued nor received so as to become assessable.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Chamanlal Mangaldas Co.

court_reasoning.text: Facts almost identical to Commissioner of Income-tax v. Chamanlal Mangaldas Co.; principle applies: right to commission ceased under original agreement during previous year.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Larger sum only hypothetical income if old agreement continued.

court_reasoning.text: Income tax on income; if no income results, no tax, despite book entry of hypothetical income.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Substance over form: accrual or receipt based on actual income.

court_reasoning.text: Where income received and later given up but remains income of recipient, tax payable; but here income did not result at all.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No accrual or receipt of larger income.

court_reasoning.text: Agreements within previous year replaced earlier ones, altered rate; income consisted of lesser amounts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Book entry not income unless actually resulted.

court_reasoning.text: Not a gift; reduction part of agreement to secure long-term managing agency for floated companies.

holdings.text: Larger income neither accrued nor was received by assessee firm.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Chamanlal Mangaldas Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Bombay High Court decision approved by Supreme Court; identical facts, income neither accrued nor received due to agreement during previous year reducing commission.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; permissibility of expenditure if income accrued.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Bombay High Court: answered first question in negative; larger commission neither accrued nor received in previous year 1948-49.
outcome.relief_granted: Assessment reduced by deleting extra commission.

key_quotes.text: Income tax is a levy on income... if income does not result at all, there cannot be a tax, even though in book-keeping, an entry is made about a hypothetical income which does not materialize.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle distinguishing accrual/receipt from hypothetical book entries.

key_quotes.text: A mere book-keeping entry cannot be income, unless income has actually resulted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects reliance on mercantile accounting entries alone.
